title-group.subtitle: The Effectiveness of Education on Its Barriers and Acceptability

author-notes.corresp: Gerald C. H. Koh, Department of Epidemiology and Public Health, Yong Loo Lin School of Medicine, National University of Singapore, National University Health System, #03-20, Block MD3, 16 Medical Drive, Singapore 117597 Email: ephkohch@nus.edu.sg

abstract.p: To assess the awareness and acceptability of colorectal cancer (CRC) screening in noncompliant Singaporeans and to determine if their barriers can be overcome by education. A questionnaire developed from thematic analysis of open-ended interviews with 72 subjects was administered to 580 residents in a local high-rise housing estate. Participants aware of CRC screening were assessed for barriers and acceptability of CRC screening. All participants were subsequently educated about CRC screening and reassessed for barriers and acceptance. Those keen for fecal occult blood testing (FOBT) were offered FOBT kits and followed up. CRC screening awareness was poor. Having no symptoms was the most common barrier. More barriers to FOBT than to colonoscopy were reduced with education. After education, acceptability toward FOBT increased but rejection rates rose even higher. FOBT is probably Singapore’s most acceptable screening modality. Education is limited by barriers, which need to be overcome by alternative measures.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: With an average of 1455 cases reported per annum1 and 580 deaths per year,2 colorectal cancer (CRC) accounts for significant mortality and is the most common cancer among men and women in Singapore. Early detection with prompt intervention is currently the most effective method of reducing CRC-related mortality given that the disease runs a protracted course, with lesions typically progressing from premalignant to malignant over a prolonged period, and the 5-year survival rate decreasing from 80% to 95% in stage I to less than 7% in stage IV disease.3

Unfortunately, stage I disease suffers from a paucity of symptoms and the majority (71.5%) of lesions are only detected after local invasion or distant metastasis.4 Screening is currently the only means of circumventing this problem, and many different modalities exist, with fecal occult blood testing (FOBT) and colonoscopy being the mainstays in Singapore. The effectiveness of FOBT in reducing CRC associated mortality has been substantiated by several large-scale randomized control trials.5 On the other hand, colonoscopy, although endowed with higher sensitivity and specificity rates and proven to improve diagnostic rates of premalignant and malignant lesions,6 suffers from a lack of evidence with regards to its ability as a screening tool7 to reduce CRC-associated mortality.

The superiority of either colonoscopy or FOBT is currently the subject of much debate,5-7 and it is thus perhaps more prudent to suggest that local circumstances, especially the relative acceptability of one over the other, should dictate which modality be preferentially instituted in any community. In Singapore, although both FOBT and colonoscopy are currently available, screening remains largely opportunistic and no concerted effort has been made to encourage the local population to undergo regular screening (only 3.8% of the target population undergoes FOBT at the correct frequency and only 11.2% have ever had a colonoscopy).8

There is currently a lack of studies that attempt to discern which modality is more acceptable to the Singaporean population or the barriers that prevent the initiation and maintenance of regular screening. Our study thus seeks to determine, among the underscreened population, the awareness of CRC screening, the acceptability of CRC screening by either colonoscopy or FOBT, the barriers to screening for each modality, and the effectiveness of education in overcoming these barriers and increasing acceptance.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: We conducted a community-based cross-sectional study of persons living within a residential estate in central Singapore. The estate consists mainly of public high-rise Housing Development Board apartments, which constitute 85.1% of all housing units in Singapore.9

sec.title: Study Population
sec.p: We randomly selected 2804 out of 5078 household units (HHU) and conducted door-to-door interviews on eligible subjects. If an eligible subject was unavailable at the time of interview, a separate visit was arranged. If all eligible members of a HHU were not contactable on 3 separate occasions (over at least 1 weekend), the HHU was replaced with another randomly selected one.

sec.title: Eligibility Criteria
sec.p: As we aimed to survey the local underscreened population, the eligibility criteria for our study were as follows: participants had to be (1) either Singaporean or Permanent Resident, (2) aged 50 years or older, and (3) non-concordant with CRC screening frequency as stipulated in the Ministry of Health clinical practice guidelines.10 Participants with a history of cancer or a previous colectomy were excluded, as they were more likely to have a greater general awareness of CRC and CRC screening.

sec.title: Questionnaire development
sec.p: We used an exploratory sequential design mixed methods approach to assess the awareness, perceived barriers and acceptance of participants to CRC screening.11 In the first (qualitative) phase of this study, we explored awareness of and common barriers to CRC screening by means of in-depth interviews using a semistructured open-ended interview guide with 3 probing questions administered to 72 purposively sampled individuals who fulfilled the above eligibility criteria. Interviews were recorded verbatim and transcribed into English if necessary.

We then performed thematic analysis to explore key findings (Table 1). Based on these results and literature reviews of previous studies on common barriers to CRC screening,12-18 a questionnaire was developed for the second (quantitative) phase (available on request). This questionnaire was translated into the other 3 main languages of our multiethnic country (ie, Malay, Chinese, and Tamil) to minimize translation errors and variation during interviews.

caption.p: Probing Questions for Qualitative Study and Representative Responses

tr.td: How often do you think you are recommended to go for colorectal cancer screening?

Male, 73 years, Chinese: “Nobody told me to screen for it. My father died of what I think is colon cancer. I do not know if it is hereditary. I really do not know how often I am recommended to go. I opportunity is provided by the company or the community centre, I would go. I would not mind paying a little even.”
How do you think colorectal cancer screening is performed?
Female, 51 years, Chinese: “Oh I think it depends on if you got family history or not. Can test the stool for blood. Also can do blood tests for cancer.”
Why did you not go for colorectal cancer screening in the past 1 year?

Male, 50 years, Chinese: “I feel fine and healthy. My defecation is fine and there is no blood or anything in my stools so it’s a waste of time and money to go for colorectal cancer screening. If I have symptoms, then I’ll go to see the doctor.”

Male, 50 years, Chinese: “Isn’t colorectal cancer screening very troublesome? People who are not sick have to go down to the hospital just for screening. [When the option of home fecal occult blood testing was explained] If I had known it could be so convenient, I would’ve gone for colorectal cancer screening earlier.”

Male, 52 years, Chinese: “I don’t want to know the results so I rather not go for the colon cancer screening test. Early detection is supposed to be a good thing but I still rather not think about it.”

Male, 55 years, Chinese: “If I’m destined to get cancer, then there’s nothing I can do about it. We all have to die some day. Moreover, cancer treatment is so terrible that if I get cancer, I rather just die.”

Male, 54 years, Chinese: “I am not sure I want to go for colorectal cancer screening because there is always a fear that one really has cancer. And some cancers are not curable so there is a fear of knowing that one has cancer and there is nothing much you can do about it. So I would rather not know unless I am experiencing symptoms that are really bothering me . . .”

Male, 45 years, Chinese: “I don’t need to go for colorectal cancer screening because I drink organic drinks to clear my intestines and keep myself healthy. I drink natural phyllium husk now and then and it lubricates the intestinal tract and helps constipation.”
Female, 49 years, Chinese: “I take a lot of fruit and vegetables daily as a preventive measure, so I don’t think I’m at high risk of getting the (colorectal) cancer.”

Female, 64 years, Chinese: “I’ve been busy with work and looking after the family. When I go home, I’m so tired I can’t take out extra time to go down to the hospital. And the queue’s really long in hospital, right?”
Male, 53 years, Indian: “I don’t think I need colorectal cancer screening because I don’t have a family history of cancer.”

Male, 64 years, Sikh: “I have never heard of colorectal cancer screening. I was never recommended to do it and nobody has ever told me it’s available. If I had known that there are various methods of colorectal cancer screening, I would you have gone for it or at least find out more about it.”
Male, 52 years, Chinese: “I used to go for it (colorectal cancer screening) regularly but I was busy and forgot about it. Nobody reminded me to do it.”

Male, 57 years, Chinese: “I would not go for colonoscopy mainly because of the cost. If it was cheaper might consider doing it once in 2 years. FOBT is cheaper, but slightly inconvenient. If the government allows people to deduct money from Medisave (Singapore’s national personal medical savings account) to pay for colorectal cancer screening, I think people will be more willing to take part because they will not feel the pinch.”

Female, 51 years, Chinese: “Are you sure that screening can pick up cancers every time? My friend went for breast cancer screen yearly and nothing was ever detected. In the end, she detected stage 2 breast cancer lump herself using breast self-examination. I doubt the effectiveness of cancer screening.”
Male, 56 years, Chinese: “I know but it is very troublesome and the test . . . requires me to handle my stools something which I find revolting.”

Female, 55 years, Chinese: “I’ve heard that colonoscopy is very uncomfortable. I think there is no need to do that if fecal occult blood testing (FOBT) serves the same purpose and is much less uncomfortable and cheaper.”

Male, 58 years, Chinese: “I’ve heard many people complaining that (colonoscopy) is really uncomfortable with the doctors sticking a long tube in and it actually lasting quite long. It seems pretty intolerable for a long tube to be traveling around my intestines for more than 10 minutes or so.”
Female, 46 years, Indian: “It’s just so embarrassing to go for colonoscopy.”

sec.title: Assessing knowledge
sec.p: To assess participants’ awareness of CRC screening, we asked (1) whether they were aware of any CRC screening modalities; (2) if yes, which specific modalities of screening (ie, FOBT or colonoscopy) they were aware of; (3) what was the appropriate age to begin screening; and (4) what was the correct frequency of screening for the modality they named. We defined awareness of CRC screening as participants answering question (1) positively and being able to answer question (2) correctly (ie, name or describe at least one specific modality of CRC screening without prompting by interviewers).

sec.title: Assessing barriers and stage of adoption
sec.p: To explore the reasons behind participants’ abstinence from screening, common barriers derived from thematic analysis, including 10 common to both modalities, 1 specific to FOBT (fecal aversion) and 3 specific to colonoscopy (discomfort, embarrassment, and fear of complications arising from screening) were featured in the questionnaire. Acceptance of each screening modality was assessed by means of the precaution adoption process model (PAPM),19 of which only the first 6 of its 7 stages were relevant to our study. Participants initially aware of CRC screening were assessed for PAPM stage and barriers both before and after educational intervention. Barriers were not assessed in subjects initially unaware of CRC screening (ie, PAPM stage 1) before education, because it was not possible to perceive a barrier to action without having heard of that action before. Assessment of barriers and stage of adoption was repeated for all subjects after a standardized educational package, to determine changes in barrier prevalence and PAPM stage brought about by this intervention.

sec.title: Educational Intervention
sec.p: We developed a face-to-face standardized educational package (see the appendix) using public educational materials adapted to the local context from the Singapore Health Promotion Board and Singapore Cancer Society (SCS). Topics covered in our educational package included the epidemiology of CRC in Singapore, the rationale behind Ministry of Health CRC screening recommendations (eg, early detection reduces mortality and morbidity) and details of CRC screening procedures (ie, recommended frequency and details on performance of FOBT and colonoscopy) and the estimated cost. This package was also translated into the other 3 languages.

sec.title: Fecal Occult Blood Testing
sec.p: Participants who responded positively to FOBT (ie, PAPM stage 5 [decided to go for it] and stage 6 [have gone for it and will do so in the future]) were offered a pair of free immunohistochemical FOBT (i-FOBT) kits (OC Auto-Micro 80, PolymedCo Inc, Cortlandt Manor, NY) Participants who accepted were taught the procedure in greater detail using SCS brochures with photographic instructions. Participants sealed their used i-FOBT kit in a resealable bag and posted it to SCS in a prepaid preaddressed envelope for analysis. The deadline for submission of i-FOBT kits was 5 months after the survey.

A summary flowchart (Figure 1) shows the conduct of the study. Ethics approval was obtained from the National University of Singapore Institutional Review Board and participants’ informed consent was obtained.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: Data collected was entered directly into SPSS, Version 16.0 (SPSS Inc, Chicago, IL), with 3 rounds of independent data cleaning to maximize data fidelity. We used χ2 analysis to determine the sociodemographic factors associated with awareness of CRC screening modalities, the effects of having a primary care doctor on FOBT awareness, as well as the barriers associated with failure to submit samples after receipt of i-FOBT kits. McNemar’s test was used to analyze the difference in acceptability of FOBT and colonoscopy and the barriers resulting in this difference, as well as the change in barriers of each screening modality before and after education. Multivariate logistic regression was used to determine the predictors of CRC screening awareness and those barriers associated with failure to submit FOBT samples after the receipt of i-FOBT kits. Statistical analysis was performed using SPSS, and statistical significance was set at P < .05 and 95% confidence intervals were reported.

sec.title: Sociodemographic Characteristics
sec.p: Of the 2084 randomly selected HHU, 655 residents were eligible, with 580 (88.5%) eventual participants and 75 (11.5%) refusals. A total of 247 (42.6%) of the participants were younger than 60 years, and males comprised 42.1% of the study population. Those of Chinese ethnicity accounted for 87.5% of the study population. Overall, 421 (72.5%) of the participants were married; 311 (53.6%) lived in Housing Development Board apartments with 3 rooms or less; 361 (62.2%) had an education level that was equivalent to 6 years of formal education or less; and 368 (63.4%) visited a regular primary care doctor.

sec.title: Knowledge of CRC Screening
sec.p: Awareness of CRC screening in our study population was generally low: Only 117 out of 580 (20.2%) of subjects were aware of at least one screening modality and merely 4.5% (26 out of 580) were aware of the correct age to start screening. Only 12 out of 68 (17.6%) of those aware of FOBT as a screening modality and four out of 89 (4.5%) of those aware of colonoscopy knew the correct frequency at which to perform it.

On bivariate analysis, older age, male gender, non-Chinese ethnicity, and low educational levels were associated with low awareness of CRC screening (Table 2). On multivariate analysis, independent predictors of low awareness included male gender (adjusted odds ratio [OR] = 0.35 [0.22-0.57], P < .001), non-Chinese ethnicity (adjusted OR = 0.25 [0.10-0.63], P = .004), and low educational levels (6 years of education or less; adjusted OR = 0.40 [0.25-0.62], P < .001).

sec.p: Participants who had a regular primary care doctor were more likely to have heard about CRC screening (OR = 1.48 [1.05-2.07], P = .025), been recommended by a doctor to get screened (OR = 2.22 [1.04-4.74], P = .045), and to have ever gone for FOBT testing (OR = 2.60 [1.12-6.03], P = .022). However, they were not more knowledgeable about the age to start and the frequency at which to undergo screening and were not more likely to have ever gone for a colonoscopy.

sec.title: Stages of adoption
sec.p: Participants displayed greater receptivity to FOBT than colonoscopy after education (OR = 10.06 [4.06-24.90], P < .001) with positive responses (PAPM stages 5 and 6) reaching 33.0% for FOBT (Figure 2) versus only 5.5% for colonoscopy (Figure 3). However, despite the relatively favorable response to FOBT with education (increase in acceptance rate from 1.7% to 33.0%), a large proportion of participants (67.0%) still refused testing or remained undecided about adopting FOBT (PAPM stages 3 and 4) after education.

sec.title: Barriers
sec.p: Education was unable to completely remove barriers (Figure 4) for either FOBT or colonoscopy. Of the barriers persisting for both modalities after education, financial cost (OR = 17.63 [6.30-49.30], P < .001), inconvenience (OR = 27.85 [16.42-47.23], P < .001), and a lack of time (OR = 67.29 [34.12-132.70], P < .001) were significantly more prevalent for colonoscopy than FOBT, which may account for the lower acceptance of this modality. Barriers to FOBT were more amenable to change with education, with more being reduced after education compared with those to colonoscopy (Table 3). For both, the perception that a lack of bowel-related symptoms obviates the need for screening remained the top barrier after education.

sec.p: A fatalistic attitude and fear of diagnosis of cancer were barriers that were both prevalent and education resistant. Older age (adjusted OR = 1.62 [1.05-2.49], P = .029), Chinese ethnicity (adjusted OR = 4.53 [1.76-11.66], P = .002), and higher education levels (adjusted OR = 1.87 [1.21-2.87], P = .005) were independently associated with a fatalistic attitude. Female gender (adjusted OR = 2.30 [1.46-3.62], P < .001) and Chinese ethnicity (adjusted OR = 3.9 [1.53-10.01], P = 0.004) were independently associated with a fear of diagnosis.

sec.title: Immunohistochemical fecal occult blood testing
sec.p: Of the participants who responded positively to FOBT (n = 191), 172 accepted the pair of i-FOBT kits (90.0%). A total of 84 (48.8%) eventually followed through with screening over the next 5 months: 15 (17.9%) participants submitted one FOBT sample, and 69 (82.1%) returned both samples. After adjusting for fecal aversion, participants who cited “fear of diagnosis” as a barrier (adjusted OR = 0.28 [0.09-0.89], P = .031) were less likely to have submitted any FOBT samples, and those who cited “lack of reminders” as a barrier (adjusted OR = 3.61 [1.46-9.35], P = .006) were more likely to have submitted at least one.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: A lack of awareness of CRC screening is highly prevalent in our study population. After education, participants were more receptive to FOBT than colonoscopy. Education was also more effective in overcoming barriers for FOBT, especially with regards to financial and knowledge barriers, although barriers could not be completely removed for either modality. The top barriers remaining after education included the misconception that a lack of bowel-related symptoms obviates the need for screening, inconvenience, a fatalistic attitude and a fear of diagnosis. Of note, the latter 2 barriers were also resistant to change with education. Our offer of free i-FOBT kits to participants who had responded positively to FOBT after education was moderately successful with nearly half eventually submitting at least one sample.

The profound lack of awareness of CRC screening and its modalities among the underscreened (79.8%) is probably the main reason for the exceedingly low screening rates in Singapore. This suggests that current means of promoting CRC awareness may be inadequate and that concerted and proactive efforts need to be made to increase the local awareness of CRC screening. Non-Chinese, males and those with low education levels were most unaware of screening and we suggest that educational efforts be emphasized on these particular groups.

The education session administered was able to improve FOBT acceptance from 1.7% to 33.0%, suggesting that future education programs on a larger scale may achieve similar success rates. However, alongside this increment in acceptance was an even greater increase in rejection (3.1% to 51.0%), reflecting the limitations of a brief educative process in driving home key messages about screening and the limited effect that educational intervention exerts on barriers to FOBT. This group of subjects may be too resistant to CRC screening for a population-based program such as ours and may need a more personalized approach such as personalized patient education by their own primary care physicians.

Among the barriers to FOBT, “no symptoms” and “inconvenience” are the barriers most prevalent yet susceptible to change with education, hence emphasis on the need to undergo screening despite having no bowel-related symptoms and on the fact that FOBT can be self-administered may be effective in overcoming them. We also recommend that primary care physicians be recruited to actively promote and disseminate CRC screening information as supported by our results, other studies citing physician recommendation as a major factor in determining whether a patient undergoes screening7 and the fact that the majority of our study population (63.4%) had a regular primary care physician.

A previous randomized controlled trial demonstrated the effectiveness of a decision aid comprising of a video on screening and a brochure tailored to participants’ readiness to change in increasing adoption.20 Computer-based interactive sessions have also been demonstrated to improve cancer screening rates more than noninteractive video or brochure-based educative methods21 and may be considered in our local setting.

Auxiliary measures to supplement a strong educational program could include mailing kits to subjects to reduce inconvenience and the adoption of regular reminder systems, both of which have shown to improve screening rates.7 The mailing of kits directly to participants, especially, is likely to have a positive impact on screening rates, as our results show that participants who cited “lack of reminders” as a barrier were more likely to submit at least one FOBT sample when directly offered the test kit than those who did not. This strongly suggests that this barrier is likely to be easily overcome with direct distribution of FOBT kits to eligible subjects.

The greatest challenges in improving FOBT acceptance rates are the highly prevalent education-resistant barriers, namely “fear of diagnosis” and “fatalistic attitude,” which are especially prevalent among the Chinese and represent deeply entrenched sociocultural attitudes that are extremely resistant to change. In the case of “fear of diagnosis,” our results demonstrate that even with the elimination of inconvenience by means of direct distribution of FOBT kits, a fear of diagnosis was still a major barrier that determined who eventually underwent screening. This suggests that although protocols may be streamlined and screening actively promoted, uptake rates may plateau without the correction of this misconception. Evidence of effective methods to overcome these social barriers is available but nevertheless scant. A study by Sung et al12 has shown the feasibility of using lay health advisors from existing community networks to allay the fears surrounding a diagnosis of cancer. Several studies have also shown success in overcoming cancer fatalism using culturally orientated faith-based interventions.22-24

There are several limitations to this study. As the interviews were conducted by a group of 40 community health project team members, questionnaire administration could have resulted in inter-interviewer variability. However, we attempted to minimize this by standardizing our questioning and education. The presence of a control group for whom there would be no educational intervention would theoretically have been ideal to evaluate the susceptibility of participants’ barriers and PAPM stage to change pre- and postintervention. However, this was not feasible because asking the same questions to the same participant twice on one occasion ten minutes apart would be extremely awkward for both participant and interviewer. Participants’ replies on their receptiveness to screening could have been subject to a social desirability bias, but this was explored by determining the number of participants who ultimately submitted stool samples for testing.

In conclusion, this study reveals a great lack of awareness of CRC screening in the underscreened population and the value of an education program to overcome this deficit. FOBT appears to be the modality of choice for CRC screening as our results indicate marked preference of FOBT over colonoscopy among the general population. However, receptivity of FOBT after educational intervention remained low, highlighting the role of persistent barriers to FOBT as obstacles to FOBT uptake and the need to develop effective barrier-specific solutions to achieve optimal screening rates.

A number of patients do not have a family history
Screening helps pick up cancer early even when there are no symptoms
Other growths in the large intestine (polyps) may be picked up and they can be removed before they turn cancerous
When cancer is detected early, there is a good chance for cure and for a good outcome (90% 5-year survival rate in localized CRC)
Once a year for fecal occult blood testing (FOBT)
Once in 10 years for colonoscopy
